Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The influence of wildfire on food-chain length and aquatic-terrestrial connectivity: a before-after approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although wildfires are important disturbances in ecosystems in the mountains of the American West, their effects on streams remains unresolved. In particular, wildfires may have a strong influence on the way stream and riparian food webs interact, which may further influence diversity and stability of ecological communities. This research will build on three years of pre-fire research to investigate the influence of the Rim Fire, an unusually large and severe wildfire, on the interconnections between stream and riparian food webs. Invertebrate food webs will be analyzed in small tributary streams of the Tuolumne and Merced Rivers, which flow within the burned areas of Yosemite National Park, CA. The approach will consist of coordinated surveys of stream and riparian habitat, aquatic insects, and riparian spiders as well as analyses of energy pathways between stream primary producers and riparian consumers. This research will provide an empirical understanding of how wildfires may act as a disturbance agents to influence linked aquatic and terrestrial food webs.

By advancing our understanding of the short-term effects of wildfire on ecosystem function, this study will inform fire-management policy that supports maintenance and restoration of stream and riparian ecosystem services. Educational and human resource benefits from the proposed study include training of graduate and undergraduate students participating in research activities. In addition, results from this work will be shared in workshops geared toward Resource Advisors and Fire Management Officers from the National Park Service, USDA Forest Service, Bureau of Land Management, California Department of Fish and Wildlife, and California State and County Parks. Additionally, presentations will be offered to undergraduates at the University of California at Merced Yosemite Environmental Science Research Training summer semester.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation improvement project built on three years pre-fire data to investigate the short-term effects of the Rim Fire – a large unprecedented wildfire that occurred in August 2013 – on structural and functional attributes of linked stream-riparian ecosystems in Yosemite National Park. We anticipated that this research would further current understanding of how stream-riparian ecosystems respond to wildfire as well as enhance theoretical understanding of how disturbance, and other environmental factors including ecosystem size and productivity, influence food-chain length. This research is uncommon in fire studies owing to the focus on aspects of ecosystem function (i.e., aquatic-terrestrial transport of energy and food-chain length), a before-after comparison, and the Mediterranean-type climate of the study system.

Between June and September 2014, we surveyed riparian plant community composition, stream geomorphology, aquatic macroinvertebrate (i.e., stream insects) community composition, streamside habitat quality including overhanging riparian vegetation and density of large wood, and density of riparian spiders of the family Tetragnathidae, common streamside consumers. These data were collected at two stream reaches that were burned by the Rim Fire and two stream reaches that were unburned by the Rim Fire, but similar in elevation, aspect, stream size, dominant upland vegetation, and previous fire history. We also collected stream algae, leaf litter that had fallen into the stream from riparian vegetation, and tetragnathid spiders for analysis of carbon and nitrogen stable isotopes. We subsequently used the isotope data to estimate food-chain length (an important food-web metric) and aquatic-to-terrestrial energy transport from the stream to riparian spiders.

We found no change in measured ecosystem attributes in the first growing season following the Rim Fire at impact or control reaches. Companion studies we conducted in the same study system also revealed no difference in ecosystem attributes including aquatic-terrestrial energy transport and food-chain length between stream reaches paired by fire severity (i.e., one reach burned with low-severity and one with high-severity in the last 20 years). However, we did find evidence that continuous variability in fire frequency at the catchment scale, precipitation, and aquatic macroinvertebrate density was related to food-web attributes.

This study has advanced current understanding of the short-term effects of wildfire on stream-riparian ecosystem function, and results of the study have been disseminated to multiple audiences. Results to-date have been presented at the Society for Freshwater Science Annual Meeting in Milwaukee, Wisconsin in May 2015. A portion of the results of this study will be published in a special fire-effects issue of Freshwater Science late in 2015. The remaining results are currently in preparation for a manuscript to be submitted to the International Journal of Wildland Fire. Broader impacts of this work also included sharing the results of this study with Yosemite National Park in a written report as well as informally with Park scientists, where they will be used to inform fire management during suppression efforts and over the long term following wildfires. Undergraduate and graduate students were involved in field collection of data, analysis of remotely-sensed fire-severity data, taxonomic identification of benthic invertebrates in the lab, and preparation of samples for stable isotope analysis. In addition, the results of this work were presented to University of California at Merced Yosemite Environmental Science Research Training undergraduate summer semester participants at the Sierra Nevada Research Institute in July 2015 and are being incorporated into The Ohio State University coursework for both undergraduate and graduate students.
